Silksong does what Hollow Knight did well way better, and some things it did badly worse.

Positives:

‚Ä¢ Fantastic art design on just about everything, far more varied than Hollow Knight and full of little details.
‚Ä¢ Very satisfying and varied platforming. While there isn't a full on White Palace/ Path of Pain section, similarly challenging platforming bursts are weaved throughout the game.
‚Ä¢ The crests, Silk skills and tools offer great gameplay variety.
‚Ä¢ Very well designed world packed with NPCs.
‚Ä¢ Enjoyable questing system although it does accentuate the backtracking and back & forth aspects which I don't like very much but it is nowhere near as bad as Hollow Knight.
‚Ä¢ Intuitive world design. In Hollow Knight, if you are playing without a guide, it is incredibly easy to get lost for hours on end, trying to find the next upgrade. So much needless backtracking and padding because of that. Not a problem in Silksong.

Mixed:
‚Ä¢ The soundtrack is great BUT tracks are on average shorter than Hollow Knight's. Not sure why the composer chose to go with that direction but I'm hoping it'll change for the updates/ DLC.

Negatives:
‚Ä¢ Near every negative in Silksong can be chalked up to what I call excessive TCT - Team Cherry Trolling‚Ñ¢. It is there on every step of the way whereas in HK such moments would be a little less frequent: 
- Traps/ even more enemies after already arduous platforming or fighting sections, you don't get a single break really.
- Bosses that have arenas with debilitating effects (like Maggots, preventing healing), no platforms to stand on at all, add spam DURING boss fights and whole Colosseum-like gauntlets before you can even fight the actual bosses. Other bosses that'd be finely designed, have some extreme visual clutter (Trobbio) or otherwise poorly visible attacks (Lost Lace).
- Extremely and I mean incessantly annoying flying enemy design, I do not understand what they were thinking when they made enemies that fly away from you constantly, input read your jumps and movement direction for their projectiles and freak around like they are on meth.
- Cumbersome design = difficulty, apparently. The lack of QoL is very real. I do not understand why Team Cherry still think not displaying your position on the map or withholding the ability to autocollect resources that drop from enemies, basic game features present in like every other game, should be locked behind equipables? Why don't maps update in real time as well? Just unnecessary padding.
‚Ä¢ A negative that isn't specific to Team Cherry as it is present in other 2D games as well, it is however handled horribly in both Hollow Knight games: contact damage. In most other games that have CD, you have to misplay really badly and find yourself inside the enemy to be damaged. Or it could be the version of contact damage I actually like, where it is only active around whatever enemies/ bosses use as a weapon. In Hollow Knight and Silksong on the other hand, touching any single pixel of any enemy or boss at any time will immediately hurt you, sometimes even for 2 Masks worth of damage. You do not pair a system like that with enemies that move erratically and love to jump/ teleport on you, it cheapened the difficulty in HK, Silksong is no different in that regard.

All in all Silksong is an amazing game that is well worth your time when the experience isn't being dragged down by Team Cherry's juvenile trolling attempts, that I honestly thought they'd grow out of considering they were working on Silksong for near a decade, but nope, if anything they got worse with it. I've been playing Fromsoft games since Demon's Souls and have played pretty much every Soulslike there is out there as well so I have quite a bit of patience when it comes to petty trolling, only the most egregious instances get a reaction out of me but I can imagine how infuriating it would be for others that aren't used to stuff like this, so I absolutely understand the negative reviews and those that ended up dropping the game because such sections/ moments do make Silksong feel like a chore to play, especially throughout Act 3. However if you have the patience to overcome the nonsense, I can't recommend the game enough. Or just mod it out!

[h1]My GOTY[/h1]
[i]Every review is subjective and aligns with the perception, tastes, preferences and/or interests of the person writing it. I‚Äôm someone who views video games as another form of artistic expression, which is why I do NOT assign a score, I don't believe art can be measured or quantified, I‚Äôll simply share my personal experience while avoiding spoilers as much as possible.[/i]

I waited for many years for this game, so much time passed since its presentation that when I finally saw the official announcement from Team Cherry I didn‚Äôt know how to react, it was a strange feeling between excited and skeptical. It wasn‚Äôt until that fourth of September that I could finally buy it (after Steam fixed its servers xD) and from those first minutes I knew that the wait had been worth it.
The [b][u]story[/u][/b]  follows the elements of the first game: you arrive to a kingdom in ruins after its leader made bad decisions and an evil force took over everything, a few NPCs tell you about their tragedies including a talkative sword girl who masters silk and appears a couple of times to put you to the test, then your job is to find out what is behind all of this, only for the character at the end to relive some of their youth traumas related to one of their parents and motivated face the evil that is behind all of this in a place with a very marked lighting contrast (the story is more complex and more interesting than that, but I don‚Äôt like spoilers and I found that similarity funny xD). What differs from the first Hollow Knight is the way in which it expands and distributes its world, from the first scenarios it makes clear to you that it is a different environment and that the way in which you must face the challenges is far from its predecessor. Which leads me to the next point, the [b][u]gameplay[/u][/b]: this game demands too much precision both in combat and in the simple movements, since a wrong step or an imprecise attack could make you pay a high price. There was a lot of talk that it was unfair in some fights or that elements like the diagonal jump could ruin the experience, but I think it is only a matter of adapting to this new combat style, I value a lot when they dare to show something different and do not settle only with taking again elements that proved to work in the past.
The last section I would like to talk about is the [b][u]music[/u][/b], since just like its map and its story, Silksong expands this repertoire in a big way, among the tracks composed by Christopher Larkin the ones that stand out for me are: [b][i]Enter Pharloom, Bone Bottom, Fourth Chorus, Bellhart, Widow, Phantom, Red Maiden, Choral Chambers, Songclave, Cogwork Dancers, The Choir, Nyleth, Skarrsinger Karmelita, Lost Verdania, Last Dive, Lost Lace and Sister Of The Void. My emotional response to Hollow Knight, 7 years after playing it for the first time, largely comes from its novelty at the time. Silksong, largely being more of the same (although both larger in scope and more refined), does not elicit the same emotional response. Thankfully, the game more than makes up for that by being astoundingly fun to play. The world is not as tightly packed as the first game's, it's much larger, but you have been made substantially faster to compensate, resulting in an experience that feels much more ambitious and open while also allowing you to explore it in ways that range from slow, curious and contemplative to almost breakneck.

This player freedom is not omnipresent in Silksong, Act 1 is decidedly more linear and railroaded than anything following it but I think it's a design decision worth making if only because of the sheer contrast it creates when sizing it up against the amount of branching paths that the Citadel provides. This is generally one of the most memorable aspects of this game - where Hollow Knight impresses with how deep down it's willing to go, I found Silksong's initial ascent to be perfectly satisfactory but was blown away at how many new paths were available to me once I reached the top, some obvious and signposted, others mystifyingly hidden and out of the way. And there's just so MANY. There were 5 different instances in the game where I said to myself "Okay, this is the last area in the game." and I was wrong every time.

This is of course not to suggest that the game warrants praise on the strength of its bigness alone. Silksong had some big shoes to fill and an impressive world size by itself would no doubt have come short. It's a good thing, then, that the level design itself is excellent. Team Cherry have taken great strides in making every environment feel convincing and lived in, especially compared to Hollow Knight's more blocky presentation. Exploration is as tight as ever, complemented by an incredibly agile combat system that after having finished the game around 4 times I still am nowhere near getting tired of. A lot has been said about the numerous combat arenas littered throughout the world, and I was initially inclined to agree with the detractors on this one but once I really got the feel of fighting I just kept wanting more. If there's one thing to criticize about the combat it's the crest system. Incredible idea on paper and I really do love the varied movesets of each one but some of the healing mechanics mean that not all crests are created equally, to the point where some just make the game harder across the board whereas none of them should feel blatantly superior to others, especially when the conversation around the difficulty has gotten so volatile without even taking this system into account.

Is the game too hard? Well, yes, or at least it was, and Team Cherry ostensibly agreed, as since release there have been a few balance batches making environmental hazards less deadly and nerfing some bosses. Right now I think the game is in a decent spot balance wise. There's still issues to be addressed, obnoxious boss runbacks, staggered bosses still somehow hitting you for two masks of damage, somewhat punishing platforming challenges and one of the hardest bosses in the game being locked behind a tedious gauntlet that you have to do every time, but to me none of these issues are experience ruining. The game of course rewards exploration, leaving a seemingly insurmountable obstacle and returning to it when you're better equipped is almost always the right option, but something I've realized is that the game also rewards more methodical play. Even the dreaded Bilewater becomes a much more manageable experience when you take the time to properly assess your surroundings and utilize your tools (although it's still admittedly a very evil area).

Here's the thing about that, though: The tool system sucks. Using an expendable resource to use red tools is just unacceptable, it creates an awful negative feedback loop where struggling players are further punished for struggling by depriving them of an option that gave them an edge in combat, and it led to me almost never using them for fear of running out of shards. I think the worry was that tools were so overpowered and flexible that if they just had limited uses between each bench with no currency attached to them they would break the balance of the game, but even that would be preferable to the current implementation, where if you run out of shards you have to go grind for them or buy them using the also very limited amount of rosaries you come across, especially in Act 1. I think it's the game's biggest stumbling point and transforms a unique and varied system into something I almost never wanted to engage with.

That aside, though, I think Silksong improves over Hollow Knight in almost every aspect; the world is bigger and better, the combat is flashier and more satisfying to pull off, the soundtrack is simply sublime, the story is much more legible and comprehensible, no doubt thanks to the fact that Hornet can converse with the bugs of Pharloom (an obvious design decision but still one that characterizes her amazingly, especially given the game's wonderful writing style). There's so much to adore about this game that even its several shortcomings barely detract from how much I love it. There's already DLC on the way and while I'm a little afraid they'll wind back to the same mistakes they made with Godmaster, I still think it will have some of the best they have to offer.

For eight years, Hollow Knight reigned supreme as the greatest metroidvania of all time. Several pretenders tried to dethrone it, and although their efforts were valiant and they stood on their own as phenomenal games, all have failed - the Kingdom of Hallownest was too enchanting and expansive, its inhabitants too memorable; a few could match or surpass the mechanical aspects of Hollow Knight, but none could evoke its wanderlust or compete with it in style. It's unsurprising, then, that it took Team Cherry to slay the dragon of their own making.

Silksong is a tour de force so astounding it would be unbelievable coming from almost any other studio. The game's setting, the Kingdom of Pharloom, managed to capture what made Hallownest special, but it's by no means a copy. You could tell both worlds were designed by the same team, but both are original and thematically different. There is also a clear evolution in a technical aspect regarding the visuals and sound design; Hollow Knight is a beautiful and melodious game, but there is so much attention to detail and polish in Silksong that it feels almost surreal at times. When you are playing this game - if you have not already - take some time and pay attention to the sound effects and animations for things like trapdoors bulging under your weight, or just look at the background and listen to the enemies, the music, or the amazing singing of the characters that you'll meet along your journey. Silksong is so engrossing that it makes some of HK's areas seem dull in comparison, which is a batshit insane statement, but it's true.

The protagonist and plot are also reminiscent of the original, but altogether different; Hornet is our heroine and a community darling from the first game. They were wise in not making her a mute passerby, but an actual main actress and moving force in Pharloom. Her dialogue is well-written and appropriate, respecting her personality from the first game but developing her as a character. Hornet's interactions with the inhabitants of Pharloom are great and memorable, especially because many of them are also fantastic characters and fit the story's theme perfectly. I liked Silksong's plot better than Hollow Knight's, and I suspect that will be the experience for the majority of people; the Knight was a good instrument to showcase Hallownest, but Hornet managed to do the same with Pharloom while being an actual character with feelings and desires. Also, Sherma is the GOAT, and I love his song; they MUST sing it at the Game Awards this year.

As for the gameplay, I guess I will start with the elephant in the room that dominated the discourse around the game: the difficulty. HK is a "souls-inspired" game that was also considered hard by the gaming community at large, but it was quite balanced, tending towards easy for the most part; doing Pantheon Five or a Steelsoul run is probably the only genuinely hard challenge the game has without any of the crazy mods. Silksong is exactly the same. I'm still puzzled by how this difficulty discourse got this intense; my leading theory is that it's a mix of new casual players drawn by the IP's fame, and old HK players blinded by nostalgia and handicapped by a stubbornness to play Silksong like the original. They were pretty good at HK after playing the game like four times, so how come they are struggling in Silksong? Surely it's the diagonal pogo, or the fact that there are more double damage sources! No, must be the endless runbacks when you die to a boss! Game is tedious, not hard guys, I'm totally not dying 20 times to Savage Beastfly, a boss with two moves ;-)

I could not care less if someone cheeses a Souls game, that is part of the fun: use the mimic summon or nuke the boss with spells, go ahead. Here, the problem seems to be the opposite: the devs went through a monumental effort to empower the player and the enemies whilst maintaining the base of HK's combat; they succeeded, but could not predict players would REFUSE to have fun with the new tools and Hornet's increased speed and power. It's Doom Eternal vs. Doom 2016 all over again; Doom Eternal is mechanically superior, but some people seem incapable of having fun or learning: "I only used the shotgun to beat Doom 2016, why can't I do it on Eternal? Why is everything so fast? Why do I need to use all of the tools the game gives me to beat it? BAD GAME!". I know this little rant sounded very mean and elitist, but it really isn't - plenty of gamers with little to no mechanical skill will beat this game and love it. Some people just can't leave their pride or stubbornness at the door. It is what it is. If people post reviews bitching about the difficulty of a game made to be challenging and marketed as such, like Sekiro or Elden Ring, they will do it here.

Hopefully, I have dissuaded you from listening to the nonsense about this being too difficult, so I can now gush about how much they improved the gameplay from the original. Team Cherry designed Silksong to be a faster and more aggressive version of Hollow Knight, aiming for a higher skill ceiling and more variety in combat. Hornet starts similarly to the Knight in HK -except for healing, which is much faster and can be done while airborne - but becomes blisteringly faster as the game continues; the running ability, in particular, greatly improves map exploration and is such a "feels good" mechanic that it makes it hard to play HK again without the game feeling too slow. You can also swap her entire moveset by using different archetypes called crests, adding variety that the original lacked entirely. Charms are also adapted to be more proactive, becoming tools. Some tools are passives, reminiscent of charms, but a huge chunk are active damage-dealing gadgets that must be actively used by the player; they make your offensive options more flexible and often will deal as much, if not more, damage to the boss compared to your regular attacks. 

Bosses and regular enemies rise to the occasion; they are faster and have more intricate movesets to match your new arsenal. The bosses, in particular, are yet another highlight. The quality of your average Silksong boss is much, much higher than Hollow Knight's; the final act is filled to the brim with challenging and fun boss fights. Some of them are so good that it made me pretty sad we don't have panthons on Silksong yet, where we can easily rematch them. The higher quality is not surprising, as HK's best bosses are all DLC bosses; Team Cherry learned a lot, and the more they create, the better they get. Future Silksong DLC will go hard, is what I'm saying.

It would have been easy to copy Hollow Knight, but they went the distance in every area they could: better visuals, perfect audio design, memorable characters with lovely songs, faster and more engaging gameplay, some of the best boss fights in any game ever, another brilliantly interconnected and fascinating world that is a character all on its own, a protagonist full of personality and great chemistry with the rest of the cast, a main plotline filled with meaning and hope that I can't talk about as to not spoil you. I think the only nitpick I have is that the "economy" of the game is about 10% too stingy with you; literally everything else is pure cinema.

Team Cherry had every reason to play it safe and be unimaginative when dealing with the sequel to a game that was nearly perfect. Instead, yet again, they shot for the stars; it is no surprise that they landed among them.

[h1]It's Perfect, Perfect! Down To The Last Minute Detail.[/h1]

Well, it's finally here. After seven years of radio silence, Hollow Knight: Silksong is finally here, and it's amazing! I know this is a unanimous sentiment towards the game and my positive review comes fashionably late. Since Team Cherry take their sweet time developing this game, I might as well savor it bit by bit in my pace. This is the best metroidvania I have ever played. Calling it "just another Hollow Knight" is objectively correct yet woefully wrong. Silksong inherits all that makes the first game so enjoyable and doubles down in content, in variety, and in quality. Every step I take in Pharloom is another opportunity to marvel at this phenomenal art. I cannot stress enough how much I love this game.

[h2]Things I Love About Silksong:[/h2]

[b]1. A Gorgeous World To Explore[/b]
A feast to the gleaming eyes, to the indulging ears, and to the adventurous heart.
[list]
[*]Comparing to Hollow Knight's melancholy tone, Silksong's overall tone is more vibrant. The color schemes are brighter. Each area is more detailed than those in the first game. The world of Pharloom feels more alive and to a degree cheerful than Hallownest.
[*]The world is not just beautiful to behold. The platforming and biome gimmicks are really fun to traverse. Taking in Hornet's inherent agility and the new "diagonal pogo", platforming in the first area is already a demanding test to your skill, and quite frankly, one of the most satisfying test to conquer. 
[*]The soundtracks are noticeably different. Instead of having a familiar, unifying tune, each soundtrack is a unique piece of its own. It's impressive how diverse they are.
[*]As for rewarding exploration, Silksong does not disappoint at all. Secrets are all over the area. You will always find something new and interesting at the end of the road: cracked walls, hidden passages that connect the two main areas, ceiling lights that look out of place, and of course the classic "come back here when you get X ability".
[*]I also love how "optional" Double Jump is in this game. You can reach roughly 80% of the map by just pogoing on the enemies or your tools.
[*]Granting wishes is the new quest system in Silksong. These wishes are not just your average time-filler content. They contribute to the world-building and even incentivize you to explore previous areas a little deeper. Even some wishes as simple as fetch quests or currency sinks can offer visible differences in the settlement they are requested.
[*]On the same note, pay attention to what the NPCs said, especially those who have just arrived. They might give you a direction on a certain point of interest that is not marked on the map.
[/list]

[b]2. Combat & Tools[/b]
More variety, more fun.
[list]
[*]Hornet herself is so agile and diagonal pogo offers so much mobility. Usually pogoing off enemies is a way to remain airborne for a little while to avoid damage, but in Silksong pogoing gives you so much momentum to maneuver in the air. You can of course launch yourself higher so that enemies' attacks can't reach you, or you can bounce forward and immediately attack the back of your enemies. 
[*]Crest is the new item that can drastically alter your combat style. There are seven crests in the game. Each of them offers different tool slots, attack pattern, and binding. You can have the Wanderer Crest to let you re-experience Little Ghost's move set, or you can have the Architect Crest that turns your needle into a power drill.
[*]Tools replace the usual charm system in the first game. They are categorized in four sections: first is the Silk Skills. These are the equivalent of Spells and some doubles as gating abilities; second we have the offensive tools. These are consumable attacks you can weave in between your regular attacks and are replenished with shell shards at the bench; third and fourth are the enhancement tools that allow you to upgrade certain aspect of your attacks or Hornet herself.
[*]Combining all these new stuff together, the build-craft potential in Silksong already skyrockets by tenfold. I simply cannot decide which one is my favorite because they are all equally powerful. Beast Crest gives you so much forward momentum. The forward pogoing followed immediately with Delver's Drill is so satisfying to pull off; Reaper Crest's extra silk generation is perfect for Wispfire Lantern and pretty much any Silk Skills you desire. Additionally, equip Volt Filament to make your skills extra tingly; Architect Crest is the perfect "random BS go!" With Quick Sling that you throw extra items and Pollip Pouch that gives tools additional flavor, you can even kill bosses without using regular attacks once. Fair warning though, this burns through your reserved shards fast.
[/list]

[b]3. Other Compliments[/b]
[list]
[*]Boss fights are glorious but deadly performance between two(usually) strong and competent dancers.
[*]Love the species' occupation consistency here. 
[*]Act 3 is just cherry on top.
[*]The denizens of the Pharloom are so lovely.
[*]Shakra is the new cartographer, and she is amazing. Her humming is just as memorable as Cornifer's. She can even help you fight off enemies if you bring them towards her.
[*]Hornet gives her comments on every single beast she defeats is a nice touch.
[*]Hornet is such a well-written protagonist, a polite hunter who is not afraid to retaliate should you mistake her kindness as weakness.
[*]If I have a nickel every time someone approaches Hornet inappropriately and gets slapped by her, I would have four nickels. It ain't much but it's funny how this scenario happens four times throughout the game.
[*]Fleas are so cute. I love their struggling noises(?.
[/list]

[h2]Things I Dislike About Silksong:[/h2]

[b]A List of Complaints[/b]
Of course this game is not without its flaws. Since a lot of them have been discussed to death by the fans, I will just briefly mention them here and add some of my own complaints.
[list]
[*]Two mask damage is so prevalent that health upgrades feel really inconsequential.
[*]I think removing the whole shards system and letting tools replenish freely on bench could encourage people to engage in this system more often, instead of having a "fear of wasting consumables" syndrome.
[*]Early game rosary economic is abysmal. You gain so little and need to spend a lot; late game rosary economic is ridiculous. You gain so much but have few things to spend on.
[*]Needolin and Clawline should not cost silk outside of combat.
[*]I wish crafting tools on the go were not exclusive to Architect Crest.
[*]Some hatches and doors should just remain open.
[*]Comparing to the original trailer, there are a lot of cut contents in the final product, especially the Coral region.
[/list]

Hollow Knight: Silksong was given the incredibly difficult task of being the follow up to a modern masterpiece. Not only that, it had seven years of hype building up to its release. Even with a world of expectations placed on it, Silksong manages to meet and often exceed expectations placed on it, but often that will leave many players in the dust if they're not willing to change and evolve in different ways than most players might expect from a sequel. 

Silksong's world is hauntingly beautiful. Unlike the world of Hollow Knight's Hallownest, which presents itself as a long dead kingdom where the turmoil of its conflict has left scars only few can remember, Pharloom's world is still enraptured in a suffocating conflict whose effects can be felt on every character you meet while traversing the world. You can feel the weight of a civilization struggling to survive even as its crumbling institutions fight to take everything it can from its denizens before breathing a final gasp. This heavy feeling, along with a more structured narrative allowed by a non-silent protagonist, makes the world feel incredibly engaging to explore and learn about in ways that the original Hollow Knight simply didn't have the presence to immerse you in.

However, this structured world means the player has a lot more direction than they would in Hollow Knight. The entry and exit points for every new area are a lot more gated or harder to find, which means most playthroughs will end up traveling in a relatively linear path through the game. There are very few points in the game where the path forward isn‚Äôt relatively direct. A quest marker takes you to exactly where you need to go, and while there are many side paths and even (in some cases) unmarked side locations you can go to in order to progress the story, it's very rare that the player gets lost exploring some branch of the world without knowing exactly where to go. For some, this is a positive, but I found for me that it made it harder to feel like my journey was truly my own in the same way it was in the original Hollow Knight. I felt like I was on Team Cherry‚Äôs wild ride, not a path I carved out for myself. However, the path they presented was amazing and worthy of every bit of praise it receives.

One element of Silksong that will turn off many is how punishing the experience is. From its platforming to its exploration to its combat, Silksong punishes you significantly harder for missteps than its counterpart in Hollow Knight. Boss runbacks are long, and many standard enemies do double mask damage, something reserved in the previous game for only end game bosses. I‚Äôve said to a couple people that it really shows that Silksong was originally designed as a DLC for Hollow Knight. Without the baseline skills necessary to complete the previous entry to the series, this game will be a daunting task for many. This adds to the oppressive atmosphere created by every other element of the game, but for some it could be offputting if they aren‚Äôt looking to be as engaged with the game‚Äôs difficulty as the rest of what the game has to offer.

The ways in which Silksong are different from Hollow Knight are palpable and interesting but it succeeds in the ways that it's different. While the flavor is different the quality is through the rough all the same. Team Cherry did a phenomenal job with this game.

[h1]Hollow Knight: Silksong[/h1]

The bug-fantasy hyper-capitalism we didn't know we would get.

[i]Something personal ahead[/i]
Feel free to skip this part, but perhaps this small paragraph will help you understand my review.

[spoiler]Like so many, I started my journey by playing Hollow Knight years ago. With its nearly 300 hours and many more shared with friends and online content it belongs to my most played games and I can safely say that Hollow Knight is my favorite game of all time. At some point I am going to have to write a review about that game too. I can't go into all the details as to why, but this will perhaps make the expectations a bit clearer, that I had for Silksong. It was the follow-up to one of the most memorable experiences I had in my life. And it had six years to build them up.[/spoiler]


[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Where do I even start.

Hollow Knight revolutionized the Metroidvania-Genre, making other games like it a sub-genre I like to call Hollow-Likes. You've got games of all names and sizes mimicking it, one of the biggest ones clearly being Ori and the Will of the Wisp. So with its own niche in this big name we all awaited the next entry and it only ever had two choices:

1. Revolutionize upon itself or
2. Just be Hollow Knight 2

Silksong chose none.

Starting to play Silksong was like returning to an old friend that just felt different. The first few minutes I just saw Hollow Knight with wall-ledging. You even could perform the good old fly-pogo-skip to get to the first mossberry, one of the most famous speedrun skips in the original. However something was off. Enough people shared their opinion about the diagonal pogo already, but there was more. Enemies were more aggressive, did more damage, stayed out of reach. With Hollow Knight basically everything rushed to you. In Silksong you had to rush to them.

Getting to that feeling and realization was an interesting journey. Over the course of 80 hours I learned to play like Hornet, not like Ghost. The gameplay feels as smooth, if not smoother, than the first game. Precise, agile, fast, empowering, punishing. Every button press does what it is supposed to do. Every attack flies as it should. Every ledge gets climbed as long as you do it right.

The beginning was rough with the difficulty curve feeling so different than Hollow Knight‚Äôs. What I always loved about the first game was the relatively low entry barrier for its part soulslike DNA. Fighting the False Knight was so easy and so predictable and still you had to get used to the idea of a soulslike-metroidvania. However, with years in the making, the Hollow-Like-Genre now existed.

So the gloves were off.

Silksong is challenging from the get-go. You run into a wall expecting a smooth start and that threw people off. However after some time everything changes. Once you learn to play as Hornet the game becomes surprisingly easy. Or is it something else that changes?


[b]The exploration:[/b]
Leading to the second big part: The exploration. You've got yourself a world full of wonders, secrets and mysteries, bosses and lore come hand in hand. It never gets old, when you come to a room with something that you marked earlier, just to find that there is A WHOLE NEW AREA you didn't know about right there. I had that feeling with the [spoiler]Sands of Karak[/spoiler] just popping there out of nowhere. I remember being basically done with the game (or so I thought), realizing that according to Steam achievements I was still missing more than five maps.

Interestingly enough I think of Silksong as a much more linear game than Hollow Knight. Every area [i]felt[/i] like it was the only real way to go. Yes, you do learn later on, that there are different routes. But Pharloom was an empire built by a society, not a natural cave being inhabited by different bugs. It was only when I saw people missing other parts of the map than me, that I realized, that perhaps my way to approach an Metroidvania has changed.

And yet - the amount of content you could discover was off this world.

However, psychology is an interesting thing. I remember the pure joy of Hollow Knight, when beating a boss and hundreds of Geo popping out, charms being unlocked, mask shards being earned - And I remember the emptiness, when beating nearly any boss in [spoiler]Act 1[/spoiler] more often than not just leading to an unlocked story progression and perhaps some shell shards. Early on exploration felt meaningless, because there just were no real rewards and this was only reinforced by the feeling, that early-game-maps for Silksong just weren't as exciting until you reach [spoiler]Bellheart[/spoiler], as too many of them felt same-y once you leave Moss Grotto. This changes, but it does do a bad first impression.

To me, all of this ties into the world, that Team Cherry wanted to build. But more on that later.

This problem solved itself with [spoiler]Act 2[/spoiler] big times. I felt the effect setting in incredibly fast once I started that part of the game and I suddenly got rewards so fast, that I actually was progressing as a character. After that, the game got easier as you went. Power came with exploration - after you crossed a certain threshhold. It pains me to say that my itch for exploration was lessened by this simple change. However I do want to emphasize the greatness, that this game‚Äôs map goes to. The map and it‚Äôs variety is incredible with lore built right into it.

It should be fun, exploring Pharloom.


[b]The story and the Writing:[/b]

negative.review: I have love and hate relationship with this game. It is super polished and exploring the map is really fun. Some of the bosses are also super fun to fight. However, significant portion of the game is designed around being "tedious" hard than "fun" hard as other reviewers mentioned. So many encounters and runbacks are designed to waste your time. Backpedaling flying enemies, multiple massive bosses bloating your screen, platforming sections with little to no checkpoints, and many more issues drag down what could have been a masterpiece of a game.

How would you rate a game, where 80% are awesome and 20% make you question the sanity of its creators? There's a saying that if you put a spoon of shit into a barrel of honey, you will end up with a barrel of shit. This is how I feel about Silksong.

It has very high highs and extremely low lows. It's a masterpiece in world building, the level design to some extent, the atmosphere and environmental storytelling are great. Unfortunately, all of it is ruined by game design decisions, which just make the game straight unfun.

The main issue is that game does not respect your time, and overstays its welcome if you decide to 100% it. In act 2 I installed the teleport mod (and it was the only change I made to the game), because I was just tired of running around the same areas dozens of times. I get it that it's a metroidvania, and you're supposed to explore and do multiple runs of the same areas, but backtracking is really pushed into the unfun zone, especially if you're not following any guides and try to figure everything out on your own. This could have been mitigated by more generous fast travel system, like, porting to benches, or at least having a build in teleport in the game.

Second issue, and it's a big one, is how the game tries to make you feel. It raised a lot of discussions in the media regarding what makes the game fun, where lies that boundary where game's challenges are to its detriment. There was one video which made a good point, IMO, that we rarely mind the games which are difficult, but not punishing (e.g. Elden Ring), or the games that are relatively easy, but very punishing (most roguelites). Issue with Silksong is that it's both difficult and punishing. Dying is very real, happens often, and the progress setback can be tremendous.

A lot of game design decisions are aimed at forcing you in a constant state of anxiety, where you are afraid of losing your progress and resources. Platforming sections can go for a long time without checkpoints, and death can set you a few minutes back. Bosses have notoriously long runbacks, and often require you to clear a gauntlet before you can even fight them. Your tools use a resource which is not replenished after death. All of this puts a real weight on you to stay alive, and it's not a game where you can one-shot all encounters just by being cautious. A lot of platforming sections and bossfights require you to gradually learn and progress them. 

The idea here is that the more you build the anxiety up, the better it will feel when you finally overcome challenge or reach safety. Problem is that I don't feel anything apart from relief. I kill a boss and my only thought is: thank god I don't have to do it again. The game annoys you more than it makes you feel good.

There are also smaller game design decisions that just make you annoyed or frustrated. The design of flying enemies, for example. They always try to stay out of your melee range, either doing ranged attacks from the corner of the screen, or just sweeping across with a melee attacks immediately moving out of your range. It can be fun trying to figure the tactics out when you fight them for the first time, but you encounter them just so much and so often that dealing them becomes annoying simply because of how much time they waste.

The fact that TC loves to put flying enemies in gauntlets or in the middle of the bossfights does not help either. A lot of encounters end up very chaotic, and you're practically forced to tool dump if you want to keep your sanity, and it puts even more weight on you to stay alive. I think, there's a universal agreement that double bossfights don't work unless boss movesets are fully synchronized, or AI is built in a way that it's unlikely that you're fucked by overlapping attacks. TC made masterclass double bossfight in their previous game (Mantis Lords) and some good ones as well (God Eater, Watcher Knights), it's incomprehensible to me how they managed to drop the ball in Silksong so spectacularly. There are a lot of fights where you're not methodically learning the complex movesets, you're just trying to survive the chaos and clutch victory by some luck, without really feeling that you even deserved it. You're just glad its over.

IMO, the main issue of the game is that Team Cherry worked in isolation for so long. They had no outside input, they did not know whom are they balancing the game for, and they ended up making a very niche product which caters either to people who were very good at the original game (speedrunners, pantheon players), or to people who can't have fun without high stakes and anxiety.

This is a tough 'would not recommend' for me. It's honestly a 7 or 8 out of 10, but finding the fun in the game is incredibly frustrating at points, and in ways that didn't exist in Hollow Knight. 

Boss difficulty? Fine. Runback length? Actually fine, if it's too long there's a shorter way you haven't discovered. The problem for me is the myriad small ways the game just doesn't respect your time:

- MANY important things are very hidden, which means you have to hit every wall in the game if you aren't using a guide. 
- For some strange reason, they added MMO style fetch quests of 'go collect 10 bear belts' all over the game. Most of the quests are fine, and anything where you have to go kill or collect something unique is great. But this? Bleh. And there's so many of them. 
- Once you get about 60% of the way through Act 2, you've explored 95% of the map. The rest of the game has so much backtracking that the back half of the game REALLY drags. And if you want to see all the content in Act 3, you either have to rexplore the entire map again or use a guide. There's a lot of cool stuff to do, but not enough to justify the 70% of the map that has nothing new to it in this act.

Silksong has some incredibly high peaks. There are boss fights that are way more emotional than you'd expect from any metroidvania. The movement and platforming is tight (tighter and more nuanced than Hollow Knight). The art, story, and music are all on point and make for a great sequel. Would not recommend to anyone unless they really love the metroidvania genre. If you don't, I'd just recommend watching someone else play it instead.

There are a lot of things to love about Silksong. Highly detailed, smartly designed areas, beautiful music, intricate and complex fighting system, the lore that was developed with sincere care, a ton of secrets to explore... So much truly fantastic stuff that was spoiled for me by a stupidly over-the-top difficulty. 

I get it, there are games that are made to challenge players ‚Äì and I'm not a stranger to loving such projects. Sekiro and Lies of P made me swear and sweat so much that at some moments I wanted to quit them ‚Äì or smash my gamepad against the wall. Some episodes of Silksong's predecessor, Hollow Knight, were extremely unforgiving and took everything to beat them‚Äîsuch as the White Palace or the Colosseum final stage. But every time my character died in those games I felt that was fair. It was the lack of skills from my side, my impatience, my misunderstanding of games' rules. Those games were very hard ‚Äì but fair and rewarding. Every victory in them felt well deserved, well timed and brought something cool as a prize ‚Äì from a new tool to a cool plot turn. 

But Silksong... It is just a challenge after challenge after challenge. Like everything the game designer cared about was how to make player's experience more difficult. Enemies have a ridiculous amount of health, and needle upgrades don't help much ‚Äî especially in the third act. Most of them are almost unreachable for your attacks, since those are pretty evasive fliers. And there are a lot of them. A LOT: developers are obsessed with locking you in in a small room where you have to fight one wave of enemies after another. Bosses constantly spam their minions, so in addition to dealing with one lethal threat with quirky attack patterns you have to monitor another 2-3 less dangerous enemies, wasting your focus in the process. Using combat tools in such situations sounds like a cool concept, but they require resources to craft ‚Äî and you'll find that you are out of those pretty soon, and must tediously farm them. Now add the fact that almost everything in this game could kill you in 3-4 touches (hi, dear contact damage), polish it with the lack of checkpoints and the need of going through a boring runback across the half of the map on some bosses. And, finally, put some bugs with controls which aren't very user-friendly from the get-go. Now you see the whole picture.

Silksong is a great game for competitive players whose life is dedicated to gaming, I guess. Unfortunately, I'm not one of them ‚Äì and can't recommend Silksong to any relatively casual gamer, such as myself. If you are ready to dedicate a huge chunk of your time and energy to master it, and okay with all the pain of this process, you'll be highly rewarded with the things from the first paragraph. Otherwise, just save your money.

This game would be absolutely incredible if it weren't for a handful of baffling design choices and terrible balancing. The world, art, story, music, everything is top tier. Even the combat, if I ignore the balancing issues, is fun and engaging. The game has some genuinely enjoyable sections but partway through act 3 I gave in and installed mods to limit all hits to 1 mask, give more i-frames when taking damage, and allow re-spawning at the start of every room. I wish I'd installed them sooner because my enjoyment of the game increased significantly afterwards. 

The game is so close but it's problems make it impossible for me to recommend as is. 

---SPOILERS AHEAD---

1. The damage you take is insane. Enemies frequently deal 2 masks of damage, meaning early game you can take 3-4 hits before death. This doesn't change after you get your first mask upgrade since it only adds 1 health, bringing you to 6, so still 3-4 hits. On top of that enemies more frequently deal 2 masks of damage, along with environmental hazards, meaning you'll be dead in 3 hits more often than not. 

2. You get next to no i-frames on being hit. You will often be hit twice by the same attack or hit into a hazard or another enemy meaning that those 3-6 hits you get depending on how far into the game you are often more like 2-4. 

3. The contact damage is also often 2 masks. Frankly I don't think some enemies in this game should even have contact damage, let alone dealing as much damage as they do when you can get hit into them and by an attack that has already done 2 masks of damage. Worst case you end up bouncing between 3+ enemies because you don't get any recovery time and a single hit turns into a one-shot.

4. Boss runbacks are tedious at best and brutally frustrating at worst. I understand making the level a part of the boss fight in theory but in practice it just results in frustration as you want to fight the actual boss you're having trouble against so you can improve but it takes literal minutes to arrive in some cases and you'll almost certainly have taken damage along the way. The boss that then does far more damage than is reasonable because of the previous 3 points will kill you in a fraction of the time it took you to get back to it.

5. Then we  have the healing. On paper its functionally similar to hollow knights heal. But in practice it heals around half as much per amount of silk/soul you have due to the extra damage. Getting interupted when healing and losing not just 1 heal of silk but your entire bar doesn't feel challenging, it feels unfair.

The above points all sum up to make this game needlessly punishing, as if the game is expecting you to have mastered every boss's patterns before even having seen it. The game feels designed as though you should never need to recover from a mistake because you shouldn't make them in the first place. 

That alone would make this game hard to recommend but there's more I'll lay out here:

- Tools are 90% of the time useless. They feel like the "pick a superpower and the next person ruins it" thing. They all either do no where near enough damage to be a sane choice or have such a brutal downside that you'd never consider them with the balance issues I put above.

- Silk skills are also 90% useless. They take the same resource as your healing which wasn't much of a problem in hollow knight but in silk song, you feel like you desperately need every heal you can salvage so why on earth would you spend silk on frankly underwhelming skills that might not even hit (looking at you rune rage).

- The shard system just means grinding somewhere every handful of boss attempts to be able to use the tools in the fight, which isn't actually a problem until you get cog flies since, like I said, most tools are useless anyway.

- The crests are a neat idea but a handful of them feel very hard to justify using. Beast and Witch making healing even less reliable, architect having awkward as hell needle attacks, and only a couple of the crests even having a use able downwards attack really narrows the choice a lot of players will have. I personally used wanderers until I got the witch crest and was so close to going back to wanderers because of the terrible range on witch crest heal and I know for a fact other players have gotten the crest they were excited for and been so disappointed and not used it for similar reasons.

- Rosaries are hard to come by and hold onto and the game frequently makes you spend them on things that, imo, should not cost money. 

- The game almost discourages exploration. Losing your cocoon because you still hadn't found a bench after 20 minutes of trying to get through an area makes you not want to look around. And when the rewards are often unhelpful like bad tools, shards to make bad tools, or loose rosaries you'll never be able to spend, it really makes you wonder why you would want to explore a new area.

I'm sure there's more little annoyances I'm forgetting (like void attacks stealing silk for some reason) but I'll wrap up here. This game is so close to being amazing but it feels like team cherry don't want you to play it. In an effort to make hornet feel unwelcome in Pharloom, they've made the player feel unwelcome as well.

I just want to clarify that I love silksong and do strongly recommend the game. The reason for giving it a negative review is exclusively to highlight in a noticeable fashion what I believe is the biggest issue in Silksong versus Hollow Knight: acquiring currency

Nearly every enemy in Hollow Knight drops geo regardless of circumstance (except in the colosseum but you get payed at the end anyways), geo at most bounces a few times on the ground and it doesn't break on spikes meaning you can pick it up with the Gathering Swarm charm.

Silksong on the other hand decides that only enemies that would carry rosaries for lore will drop them on death. Enemies that would drop rosaries don't if you're fighting them in an "arena" setting. Rosaries bounce AND ROLL on top of breaking on spikes (and their equivalents throughout the various areas in the game) meaning that the main use for the magnet tool is to save time picking them up and/or saving any rosaries on the brink of destruction.

I can also bring up how many enemies do more damage with the relative same amount of health to hollow knight meaning that it's more likely you'll lose your rosaries in Silksong from dying. But I want to put articulate that, as someone who played Steel soul mode to 100% and then some, that my issue is not how hard it is to keep rosaries because of a skill issue. Rather, my problem is that I would rather not have to grind out the remaining amount of rosaries I need for buying both necessary (for completion) and accessory items and that I believe the combination of all the factors I list above is the primary culprit for making acquiring them more of a chore than it has to be. 

I'd be extremely curious to see how many rosaries are lost in a given playthrough due to them breaking and/or how many would be gained if enemies that are supposed to have rosaries always dropped them. 

Suffice to say: I love this game. I'm just curious as to what people's thoughts are on if this aspect is more abrasive than it should be,

It's clear that an enormous amount of craft and love went into building the game, which is why I hate that I'm giving it a thumbs down [b](TL;DR at the bottom).[/b]

My problem isn't with the art direction, performance, or animation polish. It's not even with the increased enemy damage or the new charm system - I can respect Team Cherry for wanting Silksong to be its own thing and not just be Hollow Knight 2. 

My issue is the game's underlying philosophy, the [b]way[/b] it chooses to be difficult. Silksong often feels like it [b]does not respect the player[/b].

Hollow Knight was challenging, but it was also [i]very[/i] consistent. A bench meant safety (with one famous exception). A station meant travel. Risks were rewarded in predictable ways. When the game broke its own rules, it did so both [b]purposefully[/b] [i]and[/i] [b]sparingly[/b]. You always had the sense that even if it was difficult, the game [b]wanted[/b] you to succeed, that even the hardest segments were something you could learn and overcome. From the Forgotten Crossroads to the Path of Pain, the game as a whole never felt like it was out to get you. I can only think of one time where the game made me go "Seriously?" - [spoiler]those two Kingsmoulds at the end of the Path of Pain.[/spoiler] For the entirety of the game, there was a quiet trust between the player and the developer. Hollow Knight trusted me, and I, in turn, trusted it.

[b]I found Silksong to be breaking that trust constantly[/b].


[h2]"Gotcha" Design[/h2]

Silksong often sets up moments that promise relief or reward, only to punish you instead. Some benches are traps, others require repairs that force additional parkour, and some even cost currency per use - all in a game where difficulty is higher and currency is far scarcer than in Hollow Knight. Routes are filled with "gotcha" ambushes, punishment disguised as reward, and many encounters and gauntlets that feel designed to exhaust rather than challenge. I remember finishing a tough platforming sequence with barely any health left, only to be locked into a room with a mini-boss that I had no chance of surviving. My reaction wasn't "Aw man, I'll get 'em next time." It was [b]"You didn't have to do that to me,"[/b] and that wasn't the first time I had said that. 

Someone else described Silksong as "beautiful, but dripping with malice" in their own review, and I have to agree. Hollow Knight's difficulty felt like training to grow stronger, while Silksong's difficulty often feels like someone pushing your shoulder while you lift weights. The latter is technically harder, but not as constructive or as fun as the former.


[h2]Intended Tone vs. Execution[/h2]

I didn't realize this until after I stopped playing, but according to Team Cherry, Silksong was intended as a "perfect jumping-on point for new players." If that was truly the goal, then I have to say that the game misses it completely. This does not feel like a welcoming entry to the series. It feels like a game made for people who have already mastered Hollow Knight. Add to this the fact that only a small number of people were involved in playtesting, and it's hard not to come to the conclusion that the experience seems calibrated for a tiny subset of very high-skill players. Unfortunately, not everyone is as great as speedrunners like BlackMoon or fireb0rn.

I can understand the intended tone: Hornet is in an unfamiliar, hostile land. The player should feel uneasy. But the execution comes across as antagonistic rather than atmospheric. If I had to describe it simply, Hallownest felt indifferent to you, while Pharloom feels irritated that you even showed up.


[h2]Concluding Thoughts[/h2]

Long rant aside, at some point, I realized I was playing a game that didn‚Äôt seem to want me to beat it - a game that no longer extended the quiet trust that Hollow Knight had. Once I noticed that, it became impossible to ignore. The game is definitely beatable, and I commend anyone who has done it - you should feel proud. But after completing Act 1 and a lot of Act 2 in ~24 hours of gameplay, I realized I had simply stopped having fun. Based on what I've heard about the rest of Act 2 and all of Act 3, I have no reason to believe the experience will change. I don't want to force myself to enjoy something just because I wish it were different. If you thrive on relentless challenge, don't mind the additional frustration, or if you play Pantheon 5 for fun, you will love this. And sincerely, I'm glad if you do, because there is a lot to admire here. Team Cherry crafted a game that deserves some love. But for most players - and especially for newcomers - I strongly recommend caution before you buy, or start with Hollow Knight first.

Team Cherry makes me annoyed in more ways than one. I originally played Hollow Knight on the Switch, 112%ed it, and got through all the Pantheons. I would say that it remains one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had thus far. I started to dislike the developers when they couldn't be bothered to give one sentence Tweets updating us on the progress every month or so, because I think that lack of touch with the community that originally backed their indie project is madly disrespectful. I also think now that its out that this lack of communication drives a lot of what is wrong with this game. Silksong was originally intended to be a DLC if I am recalling correctly, but became its own game because Hornet was too large to get through a lot of areas in the base game. With that in mind, it makes sense that a lot of the difficulty likely stems from the fact that this would have been played by experienced players who got through all aspects of the base game and were looking for more challenges after mastering the rest of them. However, I feel once it shifted into becoming its own thing, Silksong should have been more gradual in its introduction to that difficulty. I am not complaining that there are enemies that deal two masks of damage, I am complaining that its an early encounter that respawns once you leave the room. It is stuff like this that simply has ruined the game for me. The drapemite is a really good example. How does something like that, which spawns as commonly as something like a tiktik, come to deal two masks of damage? There were some attacks by bosses even within this game itself that dealt less damage. It is the same amount of damage as the hardest fight in the original, the Radiance. I do not understand how that can be seen as balanced, nor why things like this were not changed slightly on release. The constant flying and projectile-based enemies were also prevalent. Let me ask, which Hollow Knight players were begging for tedious run backs, bodybuilder-tough common enemies, and a bunch of primal aspid wannabes? This game had two playtesters, and it seems both were masochists who's favourite parts of Hollow Knight were the Path of Pain and AbsRad. I will say, at some point these things did get easier to deal with, though. A part of me agrees with the stance that we have simply forgotten what made Hollow Knight so enticing in the first place was the fact that it was difficult. I think there is some truth to that. If all players did was simply breeze through a carbon copy of their original favourite, then there would be no challenge, no dopamine rush, and no fun. There were parts of this game that I deeply enjoyed that did just that for me, even if they were in the minority. I really loved exploring back in areas that were once inaccessible, I really liked granting wishes - even though a lot were just repeating fetching things over and over again - and I loved the fact that we now had a visible personality for the hero. However, to there just weren't enough moments comparable to the uniqueness of Hollow Knight to make it feel good. No moment that felt comparable to getting scammed by the banker, nor the stillness of sitting with Quirrle. The soundtrack wasn't nearly as well done too, with the only memorable pieces to me being in the Cogwork area and fight, as well as the Citadel's music. No City of Tears, no Greenpath, no White Lady, no White Palace where it fits the theme and sounds like heaven. I could recite where each piece played in the original, but this all just felt like lacklustre and forgettable background noise for a large majority of the game. Combat too, to me, stayed very much the same through out. Of course there were crests and tools, but I found myself sticking to only relying on the needle and conserving my silk for heals simply because the use of weapons was too costly, especially when bosses could require a few tries for me, unlike the charms which often had some good combos to try or specific situations that made sense to use them in. Abilities too also suffered, in a few ways. In their introduction, a lot were given right before fights, like the dash and floating ability, leaving you no time to get used to them. While it introduces you quickly to how they can be used in battle, it does not do a very good job at allowing the player time to understand it, where the old set up would have the player gain an ability only after a boss fight. Gauntlets were extremely common as well, but there was little reward, and most things were behind paywalls. Just typical complaints the increasingly annoying community will reply to with a clown emoji and a "git gud." The story was a huge saving grace for me, however. I loved some of the characters and how their roles played out. Some things even made me laugh. The art never deviated from its beauty as well. But I do not have the mental fortitude to subject myself to more of this beyond what I have already done. I gave it an honest shot. I really, really wanted to like it. I knew going in that it would not be Hollow Knight, but I cannot in good faith recommend it when it takes all of the negatives and amplifies them. I was so excited, and now I feel so disappointed. I completed the base ending, and perhaps I will pick it up again and hopefully something will just click and I will adore it, but I just don't right now. And that makes me really sad because I certainly wanted to. Well worth the money though, still better than any other game that came out this year in all honesty. It is obvious a lot went into it, despite my complaints. If you are good at this sort of thing, and you actually enjoy the grind, I would say buy it in a heart beat. Otherwise if you have any remaining sanity given you didn't lose it in the wait, I would say preserve it.

Let me preface this review by saying that the game is mostly well-crafted, it's a great value for its price, I enjoyed most of the content, and I think it's a must-play for a specific audience. I wouldn't have played 58 hours of a game that I didn't enjoy.

But if I had to give a binary answer to "would I recommend this game?" Definitely not. Not to a general audience.

I played the entirety of Hollow Knight and liked it a lot which is why I picked up the sequel, but this game is leaps and bounds more challenging than its already-difficult predecessor. Difficulty alone, however, doesn't make a bad game or a game that I wouldn't recommend. It's specific design choices in this game that frequently left me confused and frustrated. To name a few: two masks of damage, flying enemies, enemy jittering (erratically flying away from you and often into you), difficult terrain in arenas, and endless amounts of gauntlets that trap you in tiny rooms with far too many enemies. I genuinely enjoyed a lot of the 1v1 boss fights in this game; some of them even did an amazing job at simulating PvP in an entirely single-player game. I had to attempt a lot of these 1v1 bosses multiple times before I learned their patterns and beat them. Despite the difficulty, these were well-designed fights and felt satisfying to overcome. I feel the same way about a lot of the tough platforming sections in the game (yes, even Mount Fay).

But all of that goodwill gets washed away very quickly when you have to challenge gauntlets like Bilewater, High Halls, and especially Coral Tower. Packing loads of smaller mobs and multiple midbosses into a small room and yelling that the floor is lava feels more annoying than creative. And this game has a wealth of creative enemies.

Now is this a skill issue? Probably. If you love the souls-like genre, have extremely fast reflexes, or are willing to challenge a single segment of the game 50+ times, I'm sure you'll love this game. But if you're an average gamer who's never played Hollow Knight or any other game in the genre before, save yourself the pain and suffering.

- You don‚Äôt have the map at the beginning of every level, you don‚Äôt know where your character is unless you use a precious slot of you crest. The levels are gigantic sprawlings of corridors, halls, galleries, in the end very similar and confusing. Very similar to Hollow Knight, but worse.
- This game doesn‚Äôt respect your time at all. I felt frustrated many times because the game demanded me to redo parts dozens of time, because there are not a lot of savepoints and fast travels. Silksong wants you to waste your time.
- Unlike the first Hollow Knight, I didn‚Äôt 100%‚Äôd Silksong. The game seems to be conceived for people who look up for guides on the internet. I didn‚Äôt want to do that, and so I have been frustrated because many things in this game seem to be hidden on purpose, to make them undiscoverable.

i hate to do this as much as the next guy but i genuinely felt like this game was actively trying to get me to stop playing from almost start to finish, spoilers ahead!

before i begin let me clear up some things: this isn't a "waaaah game's too difficult / everything does double damage / savage beastfly" review, i overall found the game's difficult to be mild at best and for a majority of the time easier or comparable to base hollow knight, just about everything dealing 2 masks of damage is a necessity as the game would just be pathetically easy otherwise, without the high damage you could quite literally tank and outheal bosses entirely, something i was STILL capable to in most mid to late game; i also don't think that everything about this game sucks or that silksong is the worst game ever, far from it, the art and music are fantastic, quite literally what you'd expect if you were to think of an enhanced hollow knight, perhaps i may be mis-remembering but it overall felt like the npcs in silksong were much more "alive" with many more player interactions which i appreciated; as for the story i can't really say much other than it's ok... but certainly didn't make me salivate to get into the lore and by the end of it i was so exhausted from everything the game pulled that i really just couldn't bother anymore; have you noticed how i haven't talked about the actual GAME yet? yeah let's talk about it.

(tl:dr)
there is still a lot of stuff that i'd like to discuss in detail but it'd be a never-ending loop of things and minor design choices that ticked me off while i was playing so instead, i just want you to know this: this game hates you, the player, you WILL be inconvenienced at every step of the way, you WILL be ridiculed and made a fool of in practically every stage of the game, and just when you're about to say "surely it can't get worse than this" for the 4th time, it'll find a way to one up itself once more; Pharloom is an exceptionally dark and depressing place in the hollow knight universe, and so too will be your experience with it.

Is it good? Yeah. Would I recommend it? No.

Hollow knight was like a coach slapping you on the back and telling you to "go get em!" It felt do-able and fair. 
Silksong is like that same guy pushing you to the ground and throwing sand in your eye.

A lot feels like being difficult for the sake of being difficult. It's like an old NES game in that aspect.
For example, the giant pit. It isn't hard, it isn't fun, you just misstep and have to walk all the way back. There's no challenge or hard enemies, it is just time consuming. I'm not sure what the vision for that was. To feel burdened? To give the player a sort of anger? It clearly wasn't for some enjoyment aspect since it's anything but that. In games like Getting over it, if you fall, you do lose all that progress. In order to climb back up, however, it's the same skill checks again. A repetition of a challenge you've already overcome to test if you are reliable at it. It's fun in that aspect, A test of might to see if your progression was just a fluke or if you are really getting better. The pit does not offer such nuance. You just walk. That is it. Maybe kill an easy enemy or two.

There is clearly some artistic vision, but it is severely held back by the brutality of the difficulty and just how unforgiving and unfun it is. Defenders will usually just say to "get good," but when the game is as frustrating as this and discourages you from attempting techniques, it's really hard to push through and keep playing.

I am usually a fan of difficult games, I like a challenge, but when the challenge feels like its all fabricated so they can have said challenge, it loses its touch.

For reference I've played Hollowknight pretty much every "Soulslike" game.  I was excited when Silksong  started playing kind of Soulslike... but I'm 44 hours in and I will tell you it gets to the point where it isn't just challenging, but way too tedious and annoying.  Like, I get what the developers were trying to go for, but I personally think they went a bit overboard.  I enjoy a great challenge, but this game just becomes annoyingly difficult all the time that it's not even enjoyable anymore.  I REALLY wanted to love this game too... womp womp.

I really wanted to like this game but it honestly feels like the developers spent 7 years getting too good at the game and ended up making this impossibly hard. I don't want to spend hours on mandatory gauntlets with 10 waves of enemies. Disappointing, as everything else about this game is amazing.
The game is unbalanced and far too punishing to make it fun. maybe ill play it again when the devs have patched it to make it actually playable for someone like me
